clean_story:
Human scents. AI decodes emotions.

"Emotion-sniffing AI" refers to systems that analyze body odor to detect feelings like fear, joy, or stress—using chemistry instead of facial expressions.

Most AI reads emotions through voices or faces.
This one smells them.
When you’re scared, your sweat releases specific compounds—like hexanal or acetic acid—undetectable to humans but clear to sensors.
In 2022, researchers at the University of Cambridge trained an AI to match odor samples from armpit pads to emotions reported by donors.
Accuracy hit 72%—better than chance, but not flawless.
Real-world test: A prototype in a VR horror game.
Players’ sweat spikes during jump scares triggered the AI to adjust difficulty in real time.
No cameras. No microphones.
Just chemistry.
Limitations? Odors fade fast.
A 2023 study found stress scents vanish within 90 minutes—useless for long-term tracking.
Still, applications loom: Lie detectors without wires.
Therapy tools for autism, where facial cues are harder to read.
Or airports scanning for "nervous" passengers—raising ethical flags.
Biometric privacy.
Synthetic emotions.
The nose as a data leak.
